symptoms: Leaves are turning yellow, plant growth is stunted.
cause: Most commonly caused by nitrogen deficiency, but can also be due to overwatering or poor drainage.
recommendation: Check soil moisture first. If soil is not waterlogged, consider applying a nitrogen-rich fertilizer. Ensure pot has good drainage.

symptoms: White, powdery spots on leaves and stems.
cause: Fungal disease that thrives in high humidity and moderate temperatures.
recommendation: Improve air circulation around the plant. Remove affected leaves. Apply a fungicide or a solution of baking soda and water.

symptoms: Small, soft-bodied insects clustered on new growth or the underside of leaves. Leaves may be sticky or distorted.
recommendation: Spray off with a strong jet of water. Apply insecticidal soap or neem oil. Encourage natural predators like ladybugs.

symptoms: Dark, sunken spots on the bottom of fruits.
cause: Calcium deficiency, often caused by inconsistent watering that prevents the plant from absorbing available calcium.
recommendation: Ensure consistent, deep watering. Avoid high-nitrogen fertilizers. A calcium spray can be a temporary fix.
